Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for ACM SIGMETRICS Conference 2011; San Jose, CA June 7-11

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project involves supporting students to attend the ACM Sigmetrics conference to be held in San Jose, CA in June 2011. Sigmetrics is the premier conference in the area of performance modeling and it is important to expose students to this conference, particularly in an environment where students tend to shy away from mathematical modeling. The students will be chosen based on a open competition and preference will be given to students who don't have any existing support or belong to underrepresented groups.

Institution.Name: Columbia University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Altogether, 45 students applied for the travel grant.  We were able tofund 21 students, including 18 US students with the NSF grant, and 3non-US students with industry support.  Most US students receivedbetween $333 and $560, depending on geographical distance from SanJose, with more distant students receiving a larger grant. A fewstudents who were only attending workshops or tutorials associatedwith the conference received smaller grants. The 3 non-US studentsreceived an awards of $750 each (for a total of $2250) usingindustrial support (HP, IBM).  The grants were decided by a committeecomposed of Dr. Giuliano Casale (Imperial College, London), Dr. MartinArlitt (HP Labs & U. Calgary) and Dr. Canturk Isci (IBM TJWatson). The committee deliberated over email until a consensus was reached.

 

The process and factors that were used to reach a decision are asfollows.  The committee divided applications into 5 categories:authors of accepted papers/posters in the main conference; non-authorsgraduating 2011-2012; non-authors graduating 2013-2015; overseasstudents; and women in computing.  A separate ranking was done foreach category based on the students' CVs.  They then funded the top3-5 for each category, trying to strike a balance between availablefunds, requested funding, and geographical distance. Non-authorstudents who were new to the conference and were coming from distantplaces were prioritized, in order to encourage participation bystudents who might not otherwise attend.  They also gave low priorityto students who had received a student travel award to the conferenceduring previous years.  The students who received the award attendedthe conference and all the student activities.
